topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Logan Kilpatrick, his role at OpenAI, and what the episode will cover: real-world AI use cases, prompt engineering, OpenAI’s operating cadence, hiring traits, and startup opportunities.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Hex and Whimsical.

topics.title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
topics.summary: Logan describes the stress and surprise of the Sam Altman/board weekend, why it was shocking internally, and how quickly the company returned to execution afterward.

topics.title: Aftereffects: cohesion and timing of the crisis
topics.summary: They discuss how the incident may have unified the team and why Logan is glad it happened earlier rather than later when stakes could be higher; shared “events” (ChatGPT launch, DevDay) bond the org.

topics.title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
topics.summary: Logan highlights mind-blowing progress in AI UX—devices like Rabbit R-1 and infinite-canvas tools like tldraw—arguing chat is only the first dominant interface and 2024 will push new paradigms.

topics.title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
topics.summary: They explore how to avoid competing head-on with OpenAI: OpenAI focuses on general capabilities, while startups should win via vertical/domain specificity or radically different experiences; examples include Harvey.

topics.title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
topics.summary: Logan discusses productivity gains from AI (especially in engineering), the value of GPTs for domain-specific nuance, and early examples like ad-writing and experiment-analysis GPTs used internally at companies.

topics.title: Logan’s planning GPT for metrics and timelines
topics.summary: Logan explains a private GPT he built to improve planning: it generates timelines, success metrics, and stakeholder lists, and forces rigor/consistency in quarterly planning inputs.

topics.title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
topics.summary: They define prompt engineering as giving models the context humans naturally need, discuss why generic prompts yield generic answers, and share practical tips (provide sources, ask it to pause/think, even small cues like tone).

topics.title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
topics.summary: Logan explains GPTs as shareable, customized ChatGPT instances with instructions, files, and tools (browsing, code interpreter, image generation, API actions), and previews monetization via the GPT Store.

topics.title: Favorite GPT examples: Zapier and learning tutors
topics.summary: They discuss standout GPTs, including Zapier’s integration enabling thousands of actions and a “Universal Primer” GPT for Socratic learning; emphasis on empowering non-developers via integrations.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Arcade (interactive product demos).

topics.title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
topics.summary: Logan contrasts Apple/NASA pace with OpenAI’s speed, attributing it to hiring for high agency and urgency, rapid cross-functional problem solving (e.g., Assistants API), and a Slack-heavy culture for coordination.

topics.title: Planning, metrics, and scaling the organization
topics.summary: They cover how OpenAI prioritizes amid massive demand (mission alignment, reliability), uses relatively lightweight planning (not OKR-heavy), measures success via adoption/revenue as proxies for compute, and discusses team size and growth.
